element.name: North Strand 1941 by toczygroszek (adopted by anacreon), Multi-cache (1/1)
element.description: This is an easy one-stage multicache. The final location is about 2 minutes walk from the start point.

long-description.p:
WWII:
During World War II Ireland declared itself neutral. Nevertheless, some German bombs were dropped on Irish land in 1940-41 killing and injuring many people and destroying some buildings. Several reasons are discussed by historians, as some of the bombing areas were strategic for Great Britain. However, the official explanation was pilot error.
Raid on Dublin:
On 31 May 1941 just after midnight bombs exploding in the distance were heard. Searchlights began sweeping the sky and anti-aircraft batteries began shooting at planes. Two squadrons of Luftwaffe aircraft began raid on the capital of the neutral country. At 1:30 am bombs began falling onto Dublin. North Strand suffered most severely as 4 high-explosives bombs were dropped here.
Aftermath:
Different reports quote different numbers of victims. One of them mentions about 29 people killed, 90 people injured and 300 destroyed and damaged houses. About 400 people were left permanently or temporarily homeless.
In 1958 West Germany took responsibility for the raid and paid compensation of IR£327,000.
Stage 1:
At this stage you will see the memorial with description, where you will find two dates.
Sum up the four digits of the year in the 1st date and call it AB.
Sum up the four digits of the the year in the 2nd date and call it CD.
The final cache is at coordinates:
N 53° 21.(B-A) D (A+B+C)
W 006° 14.(A+B) (B-A) (B*C-A)
The cache:
On the way to the cache you will pass buildings replacing housing damaged by the bomb. The cache is a micro container and includes a logbook only. Please bring your own pen.
You can visit the local library (N 53° 21.433 W 006° 14.765), where there is an exhibition of pictures taken after bombing. The exhibition will be open in May and June 2009. More information can be found HERE.

ul.li:
2010-05-07T19:00:00Z : Found it by Horge der Seher
Interesting small multi. In a discussion with friends, I could use the new knowledge. Thanks for the cache.

2010-05-03T19:00:00Z : Found it by finalharvest
hehe, one of those little things that are so well camouflaged you only see them when you are actually looking for them

2010-04-10T19:00:00Z : Found it by 3-guineas
Long walk (started at Mespil road)

2010-04-10T19:00:00Z : Found it by whiteandblack
found quickly. tftc

2010-03-04T20:00:00Z : Found it by polle
# 1371
Quick find. Nicely hidden. TFTF Log @ 10H10
Belgian Greetz [^]

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: North Strand 1941
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: This is an easy one-stage multicache. The final location is about 2 minutes walk from the start point.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
North Strand after bombing (www.fantasyjackpalance.com)


WWII:

During World War II Ireland declared itself neutral. Nevertheless, some German bombs were dropped on Irish land in 1940-41 killing and injuring many people and destroying some buildings. Several reasons are discussed by historians, as some of the bombing areas were strategic for Great Britain. However, the official explanation was pilot error.

Raid on Dublin:

On 31 May 1941 just after midnight bombs exploding in the distance were heard. Searchlights began sweeping the sky and anti-aircraft batteries began shooting at planes. Two squadrons of Luftwaffe aircraft began raid on the capital of the neutral country. At 1:30 am bombs began falling onto Dublin. North Strand suffered most severely as 4 high-explosives bombs were dropped here.

Aftermath:

Different reports quote different numbers of victims. One of them mentions about 29 people killed, 90 people injured and 300 destroyed and damaged houses. About 400 people were left permanently or temporarily homeless.
In 1958 West Germany took responsibility for the raid and paid compensation of IR£327,000.


Stage 1:

At this stage you will see the memorial with description, where you will find two dates.
Sum up the four digits of the year in the 1st date and call it AB.
Sum up the four digits of the the year in the 2nd date and call it CD.

The final cache is at coordinates:

N 53° 21.(B-A) D (A+B+C)
W 006° 14.(A+B) (B-A) (B*C-A)

The cache:

On the way to the cache you will pass buildings replacing housing damaged by the bomb. The cache is a micro container and includes a logbook only. Please bring your own pen.

You can visit the local library (N 53° 21.433 W 006° 14.765), where there is an exhibition of pictures taken after bombing. The exhibition will be open in May and June 2009. More information can be found HERE.




Additional Waypoints

FL1R1J2 - The Cache
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___

LB1R1J2 - Library
N 53° 21.433 W 006° 14.765
